results.abstract: Glenn elected to US Sen from Ohio

headline.main: GLENN IS ELECTED NEW OHIO SENATOR; Rhodes Is Closing Gap in Contest With Gilligan for Governorship FOR SENATOR FOR GOVERNOR

results.snippet: The former astronaut John H. Glenn Jr. won a smashing victory in his race for the United States Senate yesterday defeating his Republican opponent, Mayor Ralph J. Perk of Cleveland, by a margin of better than 2 to 1.

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. FARRELLSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The former astronaut John H. Glenn Jr. won a smashing victory in his race for the United States Senate yesterday defeating his Republican opponent, Mayor Ralph J. Perk of Cleveland, by a margin of better than 2 to 1.

results.abstract: James A Rhodes, former Repub Gov of Ohio, unofficial winner of Ohio gubernatorial race after having conceded on Nov 5; refuses to claim victory on Nov 6; Rhodes leads Dem opponent Gov J J Gilligan by margin of only 10,178 votes out of more than 3-million cast; Gilligan concedes defeat on Nov 6; pledges cooperation during transition period; pors of both; tally; John H Glenn Jr, former astronaut, won smashing victory in bid for US Sen over Repub opponent Mayor Ralph J Perk, leading by nearly 1-million votes; tally; Gilligan, at news conf, cites gains made by Dem party in elections--such as Richard Celeste's substantial defeat of state's long-time Repub Lt Gov John Brown (M)

headline.main: Rhodes Is Elected After He Concedes; All Precincts Report

results.snippet: James A. Rhodes, a former Republican Governor of Ohio, was the unofficial winner of Ohio's race for the governorship. But Mr. Rhodes, who conceded defeat last night, refused to claim victory today.

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. FARRELLSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: James A. Rhodes, a former Republican Governor of Ohio, was the unofficial winner of Ohio's race for the governorship. But Mr. Rhodes, who conceded defeat last night, refused to claim victory today.

results.abstract: article on '74 voting patterns and how they might effect Dems' chances to win White House in '76; notes Dems made net gain of 4 Dem Govs, and big-state Govs could do much to anchor party's Pres selection; claims, however, that range of new Dems in Cong is reminder of how hard it is to unite Dem 'family of chameleons' behind 1 Pres nominee; notes Dems owe many of their '74 gains to ticket-splitters who cannot be counted on to vote Dem in '76; lists leading Dem Pres contenders at this date as Sens Henry M Jackson, Walter F Mondale, Lloyd M Bentsen and Edmund S Muskie, as well as Govs Jimmy Carter and George C Wallace, Sen-elect John H Glenn and possibly Sargent Shriver; cartoon (M)

headline.main: Democrats: Big Field of Dark Horses For 1976...; A Wide Open Race And on the Right, Wallace and Reagan

results.snippet: WASHINGTON-No sooner were the election results In than Democrats started searching for dark clouds behind all the silver linings. There may be a certain illogical obsession in the anxious lookingover-the-shoulder on a big race won.
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON-No sooner were the election results In than Democrats started searching for dark clouds behind all the silver linings. There may be a certain illogical obsession in the anxious lookingover-the-shoulder on a big race won.

results.abstract: Sen Robert Dole, on CBS TV program Face the Nation, says Nov 5 election results indicate that Pres Ford needs to toughen up; says Ford could this yr say let's move ahead on legis to establish consumer protection agency, which was passed by House but blocked by Sen filibuster

headline.main: Dole Says Ford, His Power 'Curtailed,' Needs to 'Toughen Up'

results.snippet: Senator Robert Dole, a leading Republican conservative, said today that President Ford's power had been "sharply curtailed" and that he would have to "toughen up a little" to win election in 1976.
results.lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Dole, a leading Republican conservative, said today that President Ford's power had been "sharply curtailed" and that he would have to "toughen up a little" to win election in 1976.

results.abstract: Mass Gov-elect Michael S Dukakis says he is going to get rid of Gov's limousine and ride subway to work; bids other state officials to do likewise (S)

results.abstract: 24 1/2-foot-high stainless steel sculpture by Jean Dubuffet, entitled Milord la Chamarre, is installed in front of Seagrams Bldg, NYC, on Nov 14; Arnold Glimcher, owner of Pace Gallery, Dubuffet's agent, comments; illus (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: OFFICE BUILDINGS AND OTHER COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES

results.snippet: To Arielle Fenwick of Long Island it looked like a giant astronaut, but to her young daughter, Anise, it looked like a giant version of the Tin Man in "The Wizard of Oz."
results.lead_paragraph: To Arielle Fenwick of Long Island it looked like a giant astronaut, but to her young daughter, Anise, it looked like a giant version of the Tin Man in "The Wizard of Oz."

results.abstract: Joseph Kraft article on long list of Dem Pres aspirants that has emerged following Sen Edward M Kennedy's withdrawal from race; lists their strengths and weaknesses; illus and brief biog sketch of Sens Henry M Jackson, Lloyd Bentsen, Walter F Mondale, Birch Bayh, Robert Byrd, Frank Church, Ernest F Hollings, Sen-elect John Glenn and Repr Morris K Udall; also, Govs George Wallace, Reubin Askew, Jimmy Carter, Milton Shapp, Dan Walker, Govs-elect Hugh Carey and Edmund G Brown Jr and former Gov Terry Sanford, as well as state legislator Julian Bond; discussion of how Dem party's abolition of 'winner take all' primaries and new Fed Elections Campaign Act may affect aspirants (L)

headline.main: The Cast; With Teddy out and new rules in, you can't tell the Democratic players without a playbill With Teddy out and new rules in, you can't tell the Democratic players without a playbill By Joseph Kraft The cast The Big Five

results.snippet: The day Senator Edward Kennedy included himself out, Senator Walter Mondale of Minnesota was asked who he thought would go Into the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976. "I don't think we have time today to list them all," he...
results.lead_paragraph: The day Senator Edward Kennedy included himself out, Senator Walter Mondale of Minnesota was asked who he thought would go Into the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976. "I don't think we have time today to list them all," he joked. "Senators, governors, mayors . . . everyone, including sanitary district commissioners."

results.abstract: article assesses upset of Ohio Dem Gov John J Gilligan by Repub James A Rhodes, who is unofficial winner by 13,000 votes; former Gilligan aide James Friedman says Gov's campaign 'made every mistake possible in order to lose'; politicians say Gilligan underestimated Rhodes's 'roguish charm and strategic brilliance'; Gilligan's early refusal to confront or attack Rhodes noted; Gilligan team halted professional polling when tide was seen turning towards Rhodes; Rhodes's last-min slashing TV ad blitz reptdly was much more effective than Gilligan's TV ads; Gilligan's apparent $80-million miscalculation of budget surplus seen hurting his reputation for competence and honesty; his breach with former astronaut John H Glenn Jr, Dem who won landslide victory in US Sen race, also hurt; Gilligan admits he was not 'candid' enough and was 'trimming,' saying just enough to get elected; other issues noted; Gilligan and Rhodes illus (L)

headline.main: Mistakes by Gilligan Are Blamed for Rhodes's Triumph in Election in Ohio; Labeled 'Perfect opponent' Issue Crumbled New Palace Guard Drove Foreign Cars Played It Safe Ads In Cleveland

results.snippet: Gov. John J. Gilligan's defeat for re-election 10 days ago was nowhere near as simple as his morning-after explanation that it was a "repudiation of me," in the opinion of many involved in the campaign.

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHE LYDONSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Gov. John J. Gilligan's defeat for re-election 10 days ago was nowhere near as simple as his morning-after explanation that it was a "repudiation of me," in the opinion of many involved in the campaign.

results.abstract: Pioneer 11 spacecraft continues voyage to Jupiter; is 2.5-million mi away from target point off Jupiter and will pass within 26,000 mi of planet (S)

headline.main: PIONEER SCANS SITE FOR JOVIAN MISSION

results.snippet: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 29--Speeding closer to Jupiter, Pioneer II searched today for a possible landing place for an astronaut. Jupiter, a planet 1,300 times bigger than earth, is a mass of gas and liquid hydrogen that would be inhospitable to...
results.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 29--Speeding closer to Jupiter, Pioneer II searched today for a possible landing place for an astronaut. Jupiter, a planet 1,300 times bigger than earth, is a mass of gas and liquid hydrogen that would be inhospitable to man. It is surrounded by radiation belts.
